description.narrative: Up to November 2011, 21 governments have publicly stated their commitment to scale up nutrition in their development programmes, plans and strategies. In so doing, these countries are called upon (i) to take stock of the nutritional situation and of existing strategies, actors and programmes (ii) to develop national plans for scaling-up nutrition and (iii) to rapidly scale-up programmes with domestic and external financing. Therefore, each Government has adopted specific targets that are quantifiable, time-bound and laid out in revised policies and strategies. Under the overall goal of improving the quality and implementation of policies and programmes delivering sustainable reductions in under nutrition in countries committed to scale-up nutrition between 2012 and 2015, the following four objectives will be sought through this credit proposal: (1) To foster civil society-led advocacy through strong, inclusive and sustainable partnerships; (2) To build, or strengthen, CSOs’ influencing capacity and ensure their engagement in SUN (Scaling-Up Nutrition) at country level; (3) To foster high-profile “nutrition champions” and the engagement of the public and communities in support of SUN; (4) To ensure commitments are kept through improved accountability of national governments and donors. - The proposal for “Mobilising Civil Society in support of the SUN Movement” provides an aligned framework for improved coordination, harmonization and mutual accountability of interventions at country level. A rapid scaling up of coordinated civil society policy, advocacy and campaigning actions during 2012-2014 will have multiple benefits on the quality, ownership, acceptance and consistence of all nutrition-related interventions at country level. It also provides a critical link to affected communities, whose voices have been too often neglected in formulating and monitoring relevant policies and programmes. In each targeted country, the proposed activities can also help raise additional (domestic and international) financial resources for nutrition security. The proposal contains the summary of 11 concept notes prepared at country level
